snippet.textDisplay:
It's easier then Elden Ring 
But It is not filled with bonfires and checkpoints.
And it has a structure.
Unlike Elden Ring which has an open world that adds nothing to the experience.
Okay, you can see everything and go everywhere from the start......
...why is that a good thing?
In Elden Ring I also collect crafting materials like I'm in a f*king Bethesda game.
Just because this is what I needed in a soulsborne game.🤮
I never traverse the map with caution and excitement. I allways rush to the place I need to be.Fromsoft thankfully gave me a mount which is basically a motorcycle that helps me in the shortening boring traveling time.
And all the mini-dungeons feel randomly generated and are artistically 
worthless.
The list goes on...

snippet.textDisplay:
Lemme put this straight, elden ring is the hardest souls game out there. Your lying if you say it isn't.
Now unlike other souls games that are labeled hard  elden ring actually is
so why are other souls games like ds1-ds3 considered hardm lets start with ds1

ds1 was on o the earlier miyzaki creations, the movement wasjanky, the it boxes couldnt keep up with your dodge, and sometimes the hit box would get stuck leading to the infamous meme of im at the top of a ladder and the boss sneezed in the other country and i perished...next movement was very slow and clunky and resources were strained...but it could be easily cheesed

DS2 it was miyazakis play ground for testing new ideas....wellll the sae problem persisted through ds1 except now it was less relevent, things move faster and now all the enemies had way better tracking and for newer players this was soul crushing, but for veterans it was a mild inconviniance...but it could be easily cheesed by rnning through

ds3 the end the culmination of progress, smoother play style, faster attacks, better hit boxes, but the enemies hit like absolute freight trains with no shi's given, they had brutal weapon skills and the bosses were sometimes more tricky...but this is the easiest of the souls games...but it layed the foundation

Sekiro....this game is literaly just get gud at perrying, and deflecting, easiest game period but the mechanics made every thing muuuuch smoother

Blood born same story as sekiro

demon souls....lag central

Now we get to elden ring, you see in elden ring leveling up is a night mare and you are placed at level 11 or 1 in a lvl 125 zone, yes thats the starting level for that area if you want to deal wit just half the shi there...next is getting runes, having low low low tier weapons and the area bosses will send you to jerusalamns as they are very fast, have a serious amount of poise and will hunt you down with no mercy...next the weapons any good weapon is locked behind a decent boss fight but these fights are always tedious, because its fast, quick and hard....to get to a level where you can stmp bosses easily on elden ring is a feat as there are over 300 bosses....next areas have level needs, caelid is a 225 area, but it boast a farming spot that can be abused....next the enemies normally its just a small group but rune bears, mini bosses, random npc invasions and the fact elden rings bosses near mid game crump every ds boss end game with midto no dif, tells you sum...these bosses are so fast and accurate and have such a brutal ability set that recovery bonk is not viable

Mind you all these vis of people one tapping enemies are people who are at 400+ who have grinded the materials to get that ability, and buffs...if you were to go and watch them grind the levels, then grind through the bosses for talismens, then weapons, then the flask, and then spells...you would learn that just getting to that point makes warframes grind look like mega blox building...because any one truly new to elden ring ds pro or not....gets typically curb stomped miserably./ even veterans of elden ring have hard time running it back with allot of bosses

i dont think any souls games are easier than ds1. even demon souls. simply because, unlike demon souls, in ds1 you can get as powerfully busted before any boss(after the tutorial). so many diferent ways to get insanely powerful.

that's not saying DS1 is easy, it isnt. there are so many infuriating places, and if you dont know how useful the master key is, you will have to suffer the "correct" way to reach blight town. and the least we talk about sen's fortress the better. still, you can get so insanely strong so fast, its hard to not call it the easiest souls game from ever made.

snippet.textDisplay:
Quick tip, stop locking onto enemies and learn how to fight without it. In DS1 you can only roll in 4 directions (forwards, sideways, and backwards) this is quite limited and will kill you often as you’ll get caught rolling or roll off the arena 

If you’re not licked on though, you can roll in any direction and can better aim your rolls so that the minimum amount of the enemy hit box is touching you
snippet.textOriginal:
Quick tip, stop locking onto enemies and learn how to fight without it. In DS1 you can only roll in 4 directions (forwards, sideways, and backwards) this is quite limited and will kill you often as you’ll get caught rolling or roll off the arena

snippet.textDisplay:
I played dark souls 2, was way too hard but i just started playing when ds 3 almost came out. I bought it and got ds 1 for free.

So i thought ok lets do ds 1 first. Played the game finished it. Then ds 2 finished it but some bosses were harder for me but most bosses easy. The areas were the real pain in the game. Ds3 was even harder for me, had to really try new play styles.

Played elden ring and i cant really say what is more difficult. There were parts where elden ring was harder and sometimes not. I also played Bloodborne, it was new for me but i finished it and in the end wasnt harder than ds 3.

Thats just my personal experience

snippet.textDisplay:
Demon's Souls is the best one imo, shouldn't have skipped!!! lol. You should play the original one, on ps3 or rpcs3, the remake doesn't really have the same vibe, feels americanized all over, then changed important enemy and environments and lore-related designs for literally no reason etc, cinematics turn into call of duty fast-paced action, and all color palettes are just super contrasting and clashing colors, it's like they made zombies or fire tin cans out of every enemies vs like depraved demon-turning humans roaming desolated areas in search of souls. 

Besides, you can still play on private servers on both ps3 and rpcs3 versions and the latter has upscaled textures and all the bells (punintended) whistles so it looks pretty dope still. Visual designs are just like nothing else I swear,  and it's as ruthless as ever but also has a great progression path to explore and unique mechanics that are only in that one. Definitely my favorite to this day still. 
Hope you get to enjoy it at some point, would highly recommend the non-remake over the remake for sure though. Gameplay is practically the same anyway. 
Not like you could ever get enough souls adventures at this point anyway, amiright

snippet.textDisplay: Here’s how it is; if you played Elden Ring using every powerful tool at your disposal like the mimic summon, heavy shields, ranged attacks, quick step, etc, then Elden Ring will be easier than DS3. However, if you played Elden Ring without any of those powerful PvE tools, then Elden Ring is by far the hardest, it’s not even close. The only reason ds3 might feel easier than Elden Ring to some is because Elden Ring gives you more overpowered tools that you can choose to use, but if you don’t want to exploit those types of things and actually want to fight straight up with the bosses, Elden Ring is going to be the harder experience by a mile.
snippet.textOriginal: Here’s how it is; if you played Elden Ring using every powerful tool at your disposal like the mimic summon, heavy shields, ranged attacks, quick step, etc, then Elden Ring will be easier than DS3. However, if you played Elden Ring without any of those powerful PvE tools, then Elden Ring is by far the hardest, it’s not even close. The only reason ds3 might feel easier than Elden Ring to some is because Elden Ring gives you more overpowered tools that you can choose to use, but if you don’t want to exploit those types of things and actually want to fight straight up with the bosses, Elden Ring is going to be the harder experience by a mile.

snippet.textDisplay:
the environmental hazards are what make ds1 hard.  Like going over the rafters while attacked in anor londo, the confusing way of getting around the duke's archives while attacked by projectiles, the 2 silver knights that shoot at you when you try to enter arnor londo, the traps of sen's fortress, the cramped  fight with capr demon and 2 dogs, or the dark tomb of giants where anything can come out of the dark or you can easily fall off the edge.  the bosses and regular mobs are not really that hard.
another thing, is you can only roll in 4 directions.

snippet.textDisplay: Your shield moment was extremely relatable. Regrettably, it took me all the way to Gwynn to try one. Felt like I had to relearn a game to beat a boss. I had beat Elden ring and bloodborne before Dark souls too.  never once using a shield. I just didn’t really enjoy it much, so I didn’t use one. Funny how bloodborne has sort of a joke shield and one of your forms of defense is kinda sorta actually attack with the health steal aspect. Dark souls was the one game that got me to get over my normal fixation on doing things my own way. At first I felt betrayed by the game. Then I gave in, learned the shield rhythm, and it taught me a life lesson. Praise the sun.

Well that's cause you didn't go through this hidden wall into this secret area and find the super-double-secret item that cheeses it for you, dummy!"  You NEED a guide for DS1 or you'll never find half the GAME, let alone the items

snippet.textDisplay: humanity is tied directly to luck. 99 stack of humanity is the best luck modifier. attunement does a few things, but the most important things it does is allowing you to carry more spells, as well as it increasing the amount of times one can cast a spell. and your resistance stat literally just increases resistances or "damage reduction." resistance is relative to ADP in 3, but far greater when it comes to its stat values. it actually matters, but is probably still the least important stat there, depending on your build. if youre having problems with bleed or poison, res is a great stat.
snippet.textOriginal: humanity is tied directly to luck. 99 stack of humanity is the best luck modifier. attunement does a few things, but the most important things it does is allowing you to carry more spells, as well as it increasing the amount of times one can cast a spell. and your resistance stat literally just increases resistances or "damage reduction." resistance is relative to ADP in 3, but far greater when it comes to its stat values. it actually matters, but is probably still the least important stat there, depending on your build. if youre having problems with bleed or poison, res is a great stat.

Do you want to know what "Dark Souls" means? A lot of players still didn't know until they finished Dark Souls 3 DLC. But Dark Souls was showing us since the first game.

snippet.textDisplay: I found that bosses are way easier in Dark Souls (1-2 especially) and the difficulty lies in the areas and enemies between them. Whereas Elden Ring is all about the bosses. Haligtree excluded. It's actually a little disappointing. Hopefully FromSoft's next game (assuming that one of them is a soulslike) is more Dark Souls and less Elden Ring. By which I mean less bonfires, more runbacks, more intricate level design, and a fine balance between the difficulty of an area and the difficulty of the boss. I also missed obscure, super vague game mechanics like humanity, world tendency, and dragonsplague that added a little friction to their earlier games. Elden Ring was *way too* streamlined. Its exceptional, yes, but idk. A little less charming or whatever.
snippet.textOriginal: I found that bosses are way easier in Dark Souls (1-2 especially) and the difficulty lies in the areas and enemies between them. Whereas Elden Ring is all about the bosses. snippet.textDisplay:
I started on 2, then Bloodbourne, 3, Seikiro(only got halfway through), then Elden Ring(again halfway through so far). But im just now going through a full run-through of all 3 dark souls with essentialy a similar build for each.  

DS1 is not inherently harder than Elden Ring per se. But DS1 was the originator or scummy gimmick boss fights(Twin Gargoyles&Capra Demon for recent annoying examples).

Frankly DS1 and DS2 for the most part suffer from the same problem, 
Unlike DS3 and Elden Ring, both of which i feel have better world design overall. The older 2 are designed very much to have enemies gang up on the player at weird angles. Miyazaki really wanted players to get Ambushed like every 5 minutes. 

DS3 and Elden Ring, I'd argue, have hidden ambush spots and groups of enemies. But for the most part, aside from a handful of areas, there's usually a way to fight  and evade enemies more reasonably. DS1 and DS2 from my experience, requires you to work around and alowly through areas in a more calculated maner. 

Like DS3 and Elden Ring you can look more at as Action/Adventure games. But id consider games like Demon Souls, Dark Souls 1, and Dark Souls 2 are more Adventure with some combat. 

There isnt a lack of combat in the older compared to the newer ones, but i feel the mentality of how to approach the older vs. newer ones is drastically different. 

Old games really require more of a sense of caution compared to the newer ones. But not being able to Travel easily in 1 makes the first half of the game a pain. 

Also DS1 & DS2 both have the most egregious cheese/Gimick bosses. Some are literally just designed awefully and are actually just a waste of time to not chesse them in ways(example Summons, Firebomb over Capra Demon fog wall, Staying on the ledge of the Ruin Sentinel fight til at least 1 of the 3 is dead) 
DS3 and Elden Ring actually most of the time gives you just a fair shot to be better than the boss and learn to beat them. 
DS1 and DS2 have the most fights that legitimately midigate any skill required, and the only strategy is if you're not super over leveled is to get lucky with a cheesey strategy. 

Im all for a fair boss fight that's just hard and takes time and patience, i fully understand that as a Souls fan. But some fights in this game series actuakly just suck. 

Any Duo/Group Fight, 10000000% bullshit if you expect me to not use a Summon. Im not doing 2+v1. If they get a buddy i get a buddy. That's fair. And id argue summons are better than other players since theyre just whatever AI the game has. Its me and a Combat AI vs 2+ enemy combat AIs. Fair to me

Its a good game, but its only harder due to the level design itself, and the annoying bosses that require a cheesy method to beat reasonably.
snippet.textOriginal:
I started on 2, then Bloodbourne, 3, Seikiro(only got halfway through), then Elden Ring(again halfway through so far). But im just now going through a full run-through of all 3 dark souls with essentialy a similar build for each.  

DS1 is not inherently harder than Elden Ring per se. But DS1 was the originator or scummy gimmick boss fights(Twin Gargoyles&Capra Demon for recent annoying examples).

Frankly DS1 and DS2 for the most part suffer from the same problem, 
Unlike DS3 and Elden Ring, both of which i feel have better world design overall. The older 2 are designed very much to have enemies gang up on the player at weird angles. Miyazaki really wanted players to get Ambushed like every 5 minutes. 

DS3 and Elden Ring, I'd argue, have hidden ambush spots and groups of enemies. But for the most part, aside from a handful of areas, there's usually a way to fight  and evade enemies more reasonably. DS1 and DS2 from my experience, requires you to work around and alowly through areas in a more calculated maner. 

Like DS3 and Elden Ring you can look more at as Action/Adventure games. But id consider games like Demon Souls, Dark Souls 1, and Dark Souls 2 are more Adventure with some combat. 

There isnt a lack of combat in the older compared to the newer ones, but i feel the mentality of how to approach the older vs. newer ones is drastically different. 

Old games really require more of a sense of caution compared to the newer ones. But not being able to Travel easily in 1 makes the first half of the game a pain. 

Also DS1 & DS2 both have the most egregious cheese/Gimick bosses. Some are literally just designed awefully and are actually just a waste of time to not chesse them in ways(example Summons, Firebomb over Capra Demon fog wall, Staying on the ledge of the Ruin Sentinel fight til at least 1 of the 3 is dead) 
DS3 and Elden Ring actually most of the time gives you just a fair shot to be better than the boss and learn to beat them. 
DS1 and DS2 have the most fights that legitimately midigate any skill required, and the only strategy is if you're not super over leveled is to get lucky with a cheesey strategy. 

Im all for a fair boss fight that's just hard and takes time and patience, i fully understand that as a Souls fan. But some fights in this game series actuakly just suck. 

Any Duo/Group Fight, 10000000% bullshit if you expect me to not use a Summon. Im not doing 2+v1. If they get a buddy i get a buddy. That's fair. And id argue summons are better than other players since theyre just whatever AI the game has. Its me and a Combat AI vs 2+ enemy combat AIs. Fair to me

Its a good game, but its only harder due to the level design itself, and the annoying bosses that require a cheesy method to beat reasonably.

snippet.textDisplay:
At dragon bridge where you descend the stairs there's a ladder to a previous bonfire.
Also there's a bonfire underneath the dragon too.
The number next to your health is Humanity. This stat is more like a special currency for reversing hollow (allowing online play) and increasing your total Estus flasks you recover from a specific bonfire when resting. 
5 is Minimum
10 is Average
15 is Easy Mode
20 is Endgame
To increase you must reverse hollowing then burn humanity at bonfire you wish to give more flasks.
Some bonfires don't require this.

snippet.textDisplay:
People who say Consort is the most difficult boss are all just blinded by all the spectacle in all his moves. 99% of everything is telegraphed WELL in advanced, he has only 3 combos that can be linked to single attacks depending on spacing(and they are all side swiping moves that are all parryable), absolutely trivialized with parrying or a tank build.
Melinia is still the hardest in the game. Every single strike can be threaded into a multiple hit combo from various spacings, she steals your health even against shields,  Scarlet Rot is legit the most damaging DOT effect.

snippet.textDisplay:
So currently playing DS 3 as I wanted to play through all 3 before playing Elden Ring. I'm not saying this is true, but it actually feels like the games are getting easier that way because they keep adding things that makes the game a little bit easier like the distances between the boss and bonfires seeming to be getting shorter every time and gameplay becoming faster and smoother. 

What I'm trying to say is that you should forget ER as DS 1's gameplay is, as you realized, so different from DS 3 and ER that it can actually be a hinderance to your enjoyment of it. Slow down and be patient with each "big" enemy... DS 1 loves to punish players who are impatient. 

Also, there are three "walls" in DS 1, I'll keep it as spoiler free as possible: 
The first is the bell gargoyles boss fight, passing them is the first boss that makes a lot of people quit so congrats on passing them.
The next is Blighttown... the first part also gets a lot of people, but again be patient and push through.
The last is the boss fight of Anor Londo. If you know you know... most people that I've spoken to who quit DS 1 is with this boss fight.

Once you have passed those three fights the game starts to level out in terms of difficulty so good luck!
snippet.textOriginal:
So currently playing DS 3 as I wanted to play through all 3 before playing Elden Ring. I'm not saying this is true, but it actually feels like the games are getting easier that way because they keep adding things that makes the game a little bit easier like the distances between the boss and bonfires seeming to be getting shorter every time and gameplay becoming faster and smoother. 

What I'm trying to say is that you should forget ER as DS 1's gameplay is, as you realized, so different from DS 3 and ER that it can actually be a hinderance to your enjoyment of it. Slow down and be patient with each "big" enemy... DS 1 loves to punish players who are impatient. 

Also, there are three "walls" in DS 1, I'll keep it as spoiler free as possible: 
The first is the bell gargoyles boss fight, passing them is the first boss that makes a lot of people quit so congrats on passing them.
The next is Blighttown... the first part also gets a lot of people, but again be patient and push through.
The last is the boss fight of Anor Londo. If you know you know... most people that I've spoken to who quit DS 1 is with this boss fight.

Once you have passed those three fights the game starts to level out in terms of difficulty so good luck!

snippet.textDisplay:
Loved this - I also did Dark Souls Remastered after another souls game and found it equally as frustrating with the runbacks being soooo long.

While it may be too early to give advice about Dark Souls 2, I still want to try to spare a new player some of the easily-avoidable pain - write these tips somewhere and forget em until they're needed, if you want!

1. Level the stat ADP early and often
2. Burn the windmill
3. If you defeat an enemy 12 times, it stops respawning. So you can fully EMPTY a boss runback with grinding.
4. Enemies will chase you FOREVER, so if they spot you, you have to defeat them.
5. Covenant of the Rock makes enemies stronger.
6. Sometimes the game basically requires you to use a bow.

I hope none of that counts as spoilers, and I hope you still want to play DS2 after you've experienced DS1!

snippet.textDisplay: Yeah you gotta reverse your hollowing at a bonfire using humanity, the big grey number next to your health. You don’t have to do it at every bonfire but a good idea at frequently used spots like the blacksmith

snippet.textDisplay:
Yo're in for the adventure of your life \o/

Just please try and engage a little bit with the multiplayer aspects of the game when you feel confortable, especialy the covenants.
I think you'll feel that Dark Souls 2, for example, has a little weird progression sometimes, if you're not engaging with multiplayer. Otherwise you get some crazy covenant activity helping to tell the story of your progression with that covenant influence on some areas, is kind of like playing a different game :v

Dark Souls 1 is not that different on how much the multiplayer enrich the game. So if you feel like you have to get stronger or farm a little, usualy exploring a little bit of the online mechanics is a heck of a better time and achieve about the same results :v

Be warned tho, you'll probably come to the realization that From was a lot lazy and did some steps backwards when it comes to elden ring multiplayer design, so do this only if you're ok with that :v

Here’s every non-spoiler gameplay detail you need to know:

The top left numbers are your “humanity”. You gain it from killing enemies in an area that still has a living boss. This is often called “soft humanity” the humanity in your inventory that can be used are the equivalent to the rune arcs (and are sometimes called “hard humanity”) you consume them to heal and gain soft humanity. 

Soft humanity increases your defense for almost everything and increases drop chances. 

You can reclaim dropped soft humanity upon death in the same way as souls.

At a bonfire, you can reverse hollowing. Which is basically the equivalent to the multiplayer aspect to rune arcs. This lets you summon, be summoned, invade other players, and be invaded. When your numbers are grey, you’re in “hollow” form when they’re white, you’re in “human” form.

Invasions work differently than in ER, when you are in human form, you can get invaded. Sometimes by multiple attackers. Summoning doesn’t prevent or incur invasions. 

The soapstones are the multiplayer items.

After a critical hit, (riposte, backstab, plunge attack) enemies will take a second to stand back up, during this time, they are invulnerable. Think of it like when you perform a critical, you are invincible in ER. 

Resistance only affects poison resistance. Do what you will with this info.

In dark souls, every area functions similar to the legacy dungeons. Meaning sometimes you need to go back to them later. 

The bosses are based off the demon souls design. So, most bosses have a “gimmick” to take advantage of, or fight around. You already noted the ones for taurus demon, such as the small area and the plunge attack opportunity. If you’re having a hard time with a boss, you might be missing a major part of its details. Try looking around the arena beforehand. 

You can kick by pressing forward and attack at the same time. This basically shoves the enemy, this is good for shields and when they are on a ledge. 

You can do a leap forward by holding the roll button to sprint. Then, whilst sprinting, quickly tap the roll button again, this will cause you to jump forward and gain a bit of height. But, you will roll when you land. 

Instead of stakes of marika or extra bonfires/sites of grace. The game provides extra shortcuts to the boss arena from earlier bonfires. Many of these bonfires/shortcuts are hidden behind illusory walls.

snippet.textDisplay: It is so interesting to see you play Dark souls 1 being that I have only played dark souls 1 and am currently working on dark souls 3, like the video. Thing in the top left count is humanity, you have soft and hard humanity. Soft is the humanity you have next to your health bar, hard humanity is the ones you have in your inventory. 1 humanity and pressing "reverse hollowing" turns you human and you can summon other players for bosses and also get invaded, also can kindle bonfires to give you more estus.
